newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japanese glad over arrest in case but fears remain.
newsitem.headline: Japanese glad over arrest in case but fears remain.

text.p: Residents in this western Japanese city are relieved that the grisly murder of an 11-year-old schoolboy seems to have been solved, but shock and fear remain.

In a country renowned for its low crime rate, the beheading of the schoolboy and subsequent news that a 14-year-old has been charged with the crime has sent shock waves through the city and all of Japan.
The 14-year-old confessed on Saturday to strangling then beheading Jun Hase. The two youths were believed to have been acquainted, police said.
"The killer is a really cruel man. I am really scared," said Yuki Hatanaka, an eight-year-old girl who lives in the same neighbourhood as the victim and the suspected killer.
"We can't go out and play outside," she said on Sunday.
Parents and education officials in Kobe were equally shocked. The senseless violence among youths in the United States and some other industrialised countries is rare in Japan.
They also expressed worries about whether there are any lessons for one of the pillars of Japan's post-war success, its education system.
After the murder, the killer sent a letter to a local newspaper saying that he was fed up with the strict education system which he said had made him an invisible entity.
"It is not just the problem with the boy himself but also with the entire society, including parents and schools," said Yoshihiro Kubota, a father of three schoolchildren in Kobe.
"I realised that it is very difficult to raise children. If I were the parents of the murderer, I would be very shocked," said Kazuko Kajiura, a 32-year-old mother of two children.
She said that despite the arrest, her daughter, an elementary school student, would continue to carry the noise-emitting alarm given to students following the May 24 killing.
As people looked for what could turn a teenager into such a brutal killer, they blamed the education system but saw wider problems as well.
"It is an insult against the education system. But his parents also carried the responsibility for not caring enough," said Masahiko Mano, an 87-year-old retiree.
"I think this is the problem of Japan's entire society," he said.
Those worries were echoed in official Japan. The nation's education minister said in Tokyo that he would dispatch a senior government official to Kobe to investigate the case.
Takashi Kurihara, head of the education department in Hyogo Prefecture which includes Kobe, said he was "alarmed and confused" at the news.
He said that emphasis must be put on teaching children the preciousness of life.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto had been moved to ordering a special commitment to solving the case and hundreds of police officers were mobilised in the investigation.
At the same time, some of the cynicism that has become standard in other countries in the face of increasing brutality by young people was also apparent.
"I was not that surprised. It reflects an increasing number of younger criminals in Japan," said Nobuaki Yamagiwa, a 48-year-old businessman.
